values.title: Issue #73: Optitrack marker arithmetic based on monitor axes

summary.html:
@hsu and I have rewritten the Optitrack pose math to calibrate the pose of tracked objects relative to the axes of the monitor, not the hardcoded axes we were previously relying on. This way, the Gazebo axes match up directly with the plane created by the monitor, and the Optitrack configuration should not get messed up based on movements of the monitor or the camera.

If you're curious about the pose math, please consult us for a whiteboarding session. We are working on a way of conveying a pose math tree into the documentation.

Please note that right now Optitrack commands the model positions in a local frame, not a global frame like the Hydra or Polhemus. A future PR will use the "local frame" radio button to toggle between local and global control.

Workaround for issue #80 by @\_jrivero\_.

When libserverfixture is properly built and installed in Gazebo, we can remove the sources from `test`, but this is an intermediary workaround.

You will need gazebo installed from default.

values.description:
Previously, if no Optitrack was connected, the Optitrack receiver thread started by HaptixControlPlugin would block continuously. This caused a segfault whenever ServerFixture unloaded a world containing HaptixControlPlugin.

This pull request implements polling in the Optitrack receiver so that it knows when to exit the packet reception loop. It also fixes a bug in the construction of the Optitrack thread in HaptixControlPlugin that was causing the thread to make its own copy of the Optitrack object.

Lots of help from @caguero on this one, thanks!

branch of [PR 107](#!/osrf/handsim/pull-request/107/include-serverfixture), please review 107 first.

~~You will need Gazebo [PR 1588](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1588/1569-fix-crash-in-hydraplugin/diff) in order to run the example test without crashing in the HydraPlugin destructor.~~ merged
values.title: Poll instead of blocking in Optitrack receiver

summary.raw:
Previously, if no Optitrack was connected, the Optitrack receiver thread started by HaptixControlPlugin would block continuously. This caused a segfault whenever ServerFixture unloaded a world containing HaptixControlPlugin.

This pull request implements polling in the Optitrack receiver so that it knows when to exit the packet reception loop. It also fixes a bug in the construction of the Optitrack thread in HaptixControlPlugin that was causing the thread to make its own copy of the Optitrack object.

Lots of help from @caguero on this one, thanks!

branch of [PR 107](#!/osrf/handsim/pull-request/107/include-serverfixture), please review 107 first.

~~You will need Gazebo [PR 1588](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1588/1569-fix-crash-in-hydraplugin/diff) in order to run the example test without crashing in the HydraPlugin destructor.~~ merged
summary.html:
Previously, if no Optitrack was connected, the Optitrack receiver thread started by HaptixControlPlugin would block continuously. This caused a segfault whenever ServerFixture unloaded a world containing HaptixControlPlugin.

This pull request implements polling in the Optitrack receiver so that it knows when to exit the packet reception loop. It also fixes a bug in the construction of the Optitrack thread in HaptixControlPlugin that was causing the thread to make its own copy of the Optitrack object.

Lots of help from @caguero on this one, thanks!

branch of PR 107, please review 107 first.

You will need Gazebo PR 1588 in order to run the example test without crashing in the HydraPlugin destructor. merged

values.description:
This pull requests adds a plugin that collects information from the Gazebo world and serves responses to Haptix Sim API clients. Two integration tests are included.

* `HaptixWorldPlugin`: A `WorldPlugin` with an ignition-transport node that sets up callbacks for each API call in the [sim API specification](#!/osrf/haptix_api/src/b1b40f00decba895ed62e681e320fccc4e9ee77b/haptix_sim.h?at=default).
* `test/integration/sim_api`: An integration test that verifies the result of each sim API call. It uses `ServerFixture` and creates from scratch any structures that would usually be created by `gzclient`. Thus it's not necessarily a realistic testing situation, but it allows us to easily access and verify server-side state that is manipulated by the API.
* `test/integration/sim_api_client`: An integration test that forks gzclient and gzserver, then runs through every Sim API call and verifies that the return code is OK. This is a coarse-grained test that verifies the typical use case of the Sim API (gzclient, gzserver, and `haptix-comm` client all run in separate processes).
* `arat_test.world`: A test world based on the ARAT world with some extra models, such as a door (needed to test API calls that manipulate joints).

In order to facilitate quick review of this gigantic pull request, we're going to try something new: I will assign several people will review separate components in parallel. If you receive a `HaptixWorldPlugin` callback (`Haptix...Callback`), also review the test for it in `test/integration/sim_api`.

Please let me know if you feel you don't have time to review this PR or if you feel unequipped to do so. We can also move around what's been assigned

This also means that this pull request won't get merged until everyone who's been assigned approves it.

* @caguero: `HaptixAddModelCallback, HaptixRemoveModelCallback`, all of the `HaptixWorldPlugin::Convert...` functions, `HaptixIsLoggingCallback, HaptixStartLoggingCallback, HaptixStopLoggingCallback, HaptixSetModelColorCallback, HaptixModelColorCallback`
* @scpeters: `HaptixModelCollideModeCallback, HaptixSetModelCollideModeCallback, HaptixContactPointsCallback, HaptixModelJointStateCallback`
* @hsu: `HaptixModelTransformCallback, HaptixSetModelTransformCallback, HaptixAngularVelocityCallback, HaptixSetAngularVelocityCallback, HaptixLinearVelocityCallback, HaptixSetLinearVelocityCallback`, `OnUserCameraPose, HaptixSimInfoCallback
* @gerkey: `HaptixResetCallback, HaptixApplyWrenchCallback, HaptixApplyTorqueCallback, HaptixApplyForceCallback, OnWorldUpdate`, HaptixCameraTransformCallback, HaptixSetCameraTransformCallback
* @\_jrivero\_: Lines 0-278 (includes, destructor, load) of `HaptixWorldPlugin`, `sim_api_client` test, CMake files affected by this commit, `HaptixModelGravityCallback`, `HaptixSetModelGravityCallback`
values.title: HAPTIX Sim API implementation

summary.raw:
This pull requests adds a plugin that collects information from the Gazebo world and serves responses to Haptix Sim API clients. Two integration tests are included.

* `HaptixWorldPlugin`: A `WorldPlugin` with an ignition-transport node that sets up callbacks for each API call in the [sim API specification](#!/osrf/haptix_api/src/b1b40f00decba895ed62e681e320fccc4e9ee77b/haptix_sim.h?at=default).
* `test/integration/sim_api`: An integration test that verifies the result of each sim API call. It uses `ServerFixture` and creates from scratch any structures that would usually be created by `gzclient`. Thus it's not necessarily a realistic testing situation, but it allows us to easily access and verify server-side state that is manipulated by the API.
* `test/integration/sim_api_client`: An integration test that forks gzclient and gzserver, then runs through every Sim API call and verifies that the return code is OK. This is a coarse-grained test that verifies the typical use case of the Sim API (gzclient, gzserver, and `haptix-comm` client all run in separate processes).
* `arat_test.world`: A test world based on the ARAT world with some extra models, such as a door (needed to test API calls that manipulate joints).

In order to facilitate quick review of this gigantic pull request, we're going to try something new: I will assign several people will review separate components in parallel. If you receive a `HaptixWorldPlugin` callback (`Haptix...Callback`), also review the test for it in `test/integration/sim_api`.

Please let me know if you feel you don't have time to review this PR or if you feel unequipped to do so. We can also move around what's been assigned

This also means that this pull request won't get merged until everyone who's been assigned approves it.

* @caguero: `HaptixAddModelCallback, HaptixRemoveModelCallback`, all of the `HaptixWorldPlugin::Convert...` functions, `HaptixIsLoggingCallback, HaptixStartLoggingCallback, HaptixStopLoggingCallback, HaptixSetModelColorCallback, HaptixModelColorCallback`
* @scpeters: `HaptixModelCollideModeCallback, HaptixSetModelCollideModeCallback, HaptixContactPointsCallback, HaptixModelJointStateCallback`
* @hsu: `HaptixModelTransformCallback, HaptixSetModelTransformCallback, HaptixAngularVelocityCallback, HaptixSetAngularVelocityCallback, HaptixLinearVelocityCallback, HaptixSetLinearVelocityCallback`, `OnUserCameraPose, HaptixSimInfoCallback
* @gerkey: `HaptixResetCallback, HaptixApplyWrenchCallback, HaptixApplyTorqueCallback, HaptixApplyForceCallback, OnWorldUpdate`, HaptixCameraTransformCallback, HaptixSetCameraTransformCallback
* @\_jrivero\_: Lines 0-278 (includes, destructor, load) of `HaptixWorldPlugin`, `sim_api_client` test, CMake files affected by this commit, `HaptixModelGravityCallback`, `HaptixSetModelGravityCallback`
summary.html:
This pull requests adds a plugin that collects information from the Gazebo world and serves responses to Haptix Sim API clients. Two integration tests are included.

  • HaptixWorldPlugin: A WorldPlugin with an ignition-transport node that sets up callbacks for each API call in the sim API specification.
  • test/integration/sim_api: An integration test that verifies the result of each sim API call. It uses ServerFixture and creates from scratch any structures that would usually be created by gzclient. Thus it's not necessarily a realistic testing situation, but it allows us to easily access and verify server-side state that is manipulated by the API.
  • test/integration/sim_api_client: An integration test that forks gzclient and gzserver, then runs through every Sim API call and verifies that the return code is OK. This is a coarse-grained test that verifies the typical use case of the Sim API (gzclient, gzserver, and haptix-comm client all run in separate processes).
  • arat_test.world: A test world based on the ARAT world with some extra models, such as a door (needed to test API calls that manipulate joints).

In order to facilitate quick review of this gigantic pull request, we're going to try something new: I will assign several people will review separate components in parallel. If you receive a HaptixWorldPlugin callback (Haptix...Callback), also review the test for it in test/integration/sim_api.

Please let me know if you feel you don't have time to review this PR or if you feel unequipped to do so. We can also move around what's been assigned

This also means that this pull request won't get merged until everyone who's been assigned approves it.

  • @caguero: HaptixAddModelCallback, HaptixRemoveModelCallback, all of the HaptixWorldPlugin::Convert... functions, HaptixIsLoggingCallback, HaptixStartLoggingCallback, HaptixStopLoggingCallback, HaptixSetModelColorCallback, HaptixModelColorCallback
  • @scpeters: HaptixModelCollideModeCallback, HaptixSetModelCollideModeCallback, HaptixContactPointsCallback, HaptixModelJointStateCallback
  • @hsu: HaptixModelTransformCallback, HaptixSetModelTransformCallback, HaptixAngularVelocityCallback, HaptixSetAngularVelocityCallback, HaptixLinearVelocityCallback, HaptixSetLinearVelocityCallback, `OnUserCameraPose, HaptixSimInfoCallback
  • @gerkey: HaptixResetCallback, HaptixApplyWrenchCallback, HaptixApplyTorqueCallback, HaptixApplyForceCallback, OnWorldUpdate, HaptixCameraTransformCallback, HaptixSetCameraTransformCallback
  • @_jrivero_: Lines 0-278 (includes, destructor, load) of HaptixWorldPlugin, sim_api_client test, CMake files affected by this commit, HaptixModelGravityCallback, HaptixSetModelGravityCallback

values.description:
Due to the force control on the MPL arm in HaptixControlPlugin, the sim API call `hxs_set_model_transform` does not have a lasting effect on the arm (it snaps back to the previous position before the command). We've received a lot of feedback from teams that they'd like to the ability to place the arm in an arbitrary pose using the sim API. This quick pull request publishes to the same ignition transport topic that commands the arm pose via keyboard control when the arm model is chosen in `hxs_set_model_transform`.

To test, I recommend using the Octave API. See me or Brian if you need help getting set up with that. You could also use the C example in [haptix-comm PR 76](#!/osrf/haptix-comm/pull-request/76).
values.title: Publish arm transformations in HaptixWorldPlugin

Due to the force control on the MPL arm in HaptixControlPlugin, the sim API call `hxs_set_model_transform` does not have a lasting effect on the arm (it snaps back to the previous position before the command). This quick pull request publishes to the same ignition transport topic that commands the arm pose via keyboard control when the arm model is chosen in `hxs_set_model_transform`.

To test, I recommend using the Octave API. See me or Brian if you need help getting set up with that. You could also use the C example in [haptix-comm PR 76](#!/osrf/haptix-comm/pull-request/76).

We've received a lot of feedback from teams that they'd like to the ability to place the arm in an arbitrary pose using the sim API. This quick pull request publishes to the same ignition transport topic that commands the arm pose via keyboard control when the arm model is chosen in hxs_set_model_transform.

To test, I recommend using the Octave API. See me or Brian if you need help getting set up with that. You could also use the C example in haptix-comm PR 76.

values.description: The tactors were failing to activate because they look for device `/dev/ttyACM0` by default, but sometimes the USB devices shows up as `/dev/ttyACM1`. This pull request does a device sweep and returns with an error if none of the possible devices were found.
values.title: DRC Finals Demo: check a range of USB devices for tactors

summary.raw: The tactors were failing to activate because they look for device `/dev/ttyACM0` by default, but sometimes the USB devices shows up as `/dev/ttyACM1`. This pull request does a device sweep and returns with an error if none of the possible devices were found.
summary.html: The tactors were failing to activate because they look for device /dev/ttyACM0 by default, but sometimes the USB devices shows up as /dev/ttyACM1. This pull request does a device sweep and returns with an error if none of the possible devices were found.

values.reason: i'm looking into redoing the Arduino code so it's less overwhelming. declining this for now

values.description:
*  Fixed the bug of the handle to make the hole more easy to grasp.    
*  Made the handle larger.    
*  Set up cases of the handle orientation: towards user with / wo offset angles.   

Issues:    

*  While tested with keyboard, if the handle alignment towards user, then it is difficult to check how far the finger is to the disk, and I have to rotate the scene during this process. 
*  Duplicated the unstable issue: whenever the forearm has collision with the handle, it tends to blow up. @scpeters, do you have any suggestion on this?


Tower of hanoi rules:  

 *  Only one disk can be moved at a time  
 *  No disk may be placed on top of a smaller disk  
 *  Only the uppermost disk on a stack can be moved   

Due to the code indentation issue, I didn't update those .world file, but tested locally.  
Run `erb demo.rworld > demo.world` to test.
values.title: Fixed the Tower of Hanoi issue

summary.raw:
*  Fixed the bug of the handle to make the hole more easy to grasp.    
*  Made the handle larger.    
*  Set up cases of the handle orientation: towards user with / wo offset angles.   

Issues:    

*  While tested with keyboard, if the handle alignment towards user, then it is difficult to check how far the finger is to the disk, and I have to rotate the scene during this process. 
*  Duplicated the unstable issue: whenever the forearm has collision with the handle, it tends to blow up. @scpeters, do you have any suggestion on this?


Tower of hanoi rules:  

 *  Only one disk can be moved at a time  
 *  No disk may be placed on top of a smaller disk  
 *  Only the uppermost disk on a stack can be moved   

Due to the code indentation issue, I didn't update those .world file, but tested locally.  
Run `erb demo.rworld > demo.world` to test.
summary.html:
• Fixed the bug of the handle to make the hole more easy to grasp.
  • Made the handle larger.
  • Set up cases of the handle orientation: towards user with / wo offset angles.

Issues:

  • While tested with keyboard, if the handle alignment towards user, then it is difficult to check how far the finger is to the disk, and I have to rotate the scene during this process.
  • Duplicated the unstable issue: whenever the forearm has collision with the handle, it tends to blow up. @scpeters, do you have any suggestion on this?

Tower of hanoi rules:

  • Only one disk can be moved at a time
  • No disk may be placed on top of a smaller disk
  • Only the uppermost disk on a stack can be moved

Due to the code indentation issue, I didn't update those .world file, but tested locally.
Run erb demo.rworld > demo.world to test.

values.reason: It was too hard to make the hanoi collisions unstable. We are going with a simple shapes solution instead.

values.description:
* Text on task buttons not cut anymore

* Hide top frame (note that not only motion capture info, but also settings are hidden)

* Hotkeys: `F` is "Reset All", `G` is "Reset Models", ~~`H` is "Reset Arm" - I wasn't sure how to Reset Arm so I added the shortcut and it displays a debug message. Maybe someone who knows HAPTIX better can do the backend? Otherwise I can revisit this later.~~ (Reset arm on pull request #120)

* `F1` resets and restarts timer
values.title: DRC Finals Demo: small GUI changes

summary.raw:
* Text on task buttons not cut anymore

* Hide top frame (note that not only motion capture info, but also settings are hidden)

* Hotkeys: `F` is "Reset All", `G` is "Reset Models", ~~`H` is "Reset Arm" - I wasn't sure how to Reset Arm so I added the shortcut and it displays a debug message. Maybe someone who knows HAPTIX better can do the backend? Otherwise I can revisit this later.~~ (Reset arm on pull request #120)

summary.html:
• Text on task buttons not cut anymore

  • Hide top frame (note that not only motion capture info, but also settings are hidden)

  • Hotkeys: F is "Reset All", G is "Reset Models", H is "Reset Arm" - I wasn't sure how to Reset Arm so I added the shortcut and it displays a debug message. Maybe someone who knows HAPTIX better can do the backend? Otherwise I can revisit this later. (Reset arm on pull request #120)

  • F1 resets and restarts timer

values.description:
**Ignore this PR if you are not working on the DRC Expo HAPTIX Demo**

# Shortkeys summary:

* `F1`: The only way to reset the timer

* `F`: Reset All, i.e. all models in the current task, the arm and the viewpoint

* `G`: Reset Scene, i.e. all models in the current task

* `H`: Reset Arm

# Stack Blocks

Needs [gazebo_models pr 152](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/152/drc-expo-haptix-materials-for-blocks/diff)

values.description: The code in HaptixWorldPlugin was assuming that the `collideBitmask` value when using `hxsDETECTIONONLY` was `0x01u`. By default, the value of `collideBitmask` is 65535. This was making the test to fail. I tweaked the expectation.
values.title: Fix HxsSetModelCollideMode test

summary.raw: The code in HaptixWorldPlugin was assuming that the `collideBitmask` value when using `hxsDETECTIONONLY` was `0x01u`. By default, the value of `collideBitmask` is 65535. This was making the test to fail. I tweaked the expectation.
summary.html: The code in HaptixWorldPlugin was assuming that the collideBitmask value when using hxsDETECTIONONLY was 0x01u. By default, the value of collideBitmask is 65535. This was making the test to fail. I tweaked the expectation.

values.description:
This test was failing in the `execvp` calls for executing `gzserver` and `gzclient`. We were passing a few arguments to `gzserver` and `gzclient` such as `"--verbose"` or `"worlds/arat.world"`. According to the `execvp` manual page:

```
#!c++
The list of arguments must be terminated by a null pointer, and, since these are  variadic  functions,  this  pointer must be cast (char *) NULL.
```


Adding NULL to the list arguments seems to fix the problem.
values.title: Fix sim_api_mex_client test

summary.raw:
This test was failing in the `execvp` calls for executing `gzserver` and `gzclient`. We were passing a few arguments to `gzserver` and `gzclient` such as `"--verbose"` or `"worlds/arat.world"`. According to the `execvp` manual page:

```
#!c++
The list of arguments must be terminated by a null pointer, and, since these are  variadic  functions,  this  pointer must be cast (char *) NULL.
```


Adding NULL to the list arguments seems to fix the problem.
summary.html:
This test was failing in the execvp calls for executing gzserver and gzclient. We were passing a few arguments to gzserver and gzclient such as "--verbose" or "worlds/arat.world". According to the execvp manual page:

The list of arguments must be terminated by a null pointer, and, since these are  variadic  functions,  this  pointer must be cast (char *) NULL.

Adding NULL to the list arguments seems to fix the problem.

values.description:
While testing other pull requests, I saw some intermittent failures of the `SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo` test:
~~~
[ RUN      ] SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo
[Msg] Waiting for master.
[Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
[Msg] Publicized address: 172.23.2.90
[Wrn] [ImuSensor.cc:91] Deprecation: IMU noise SDF value have changed. Please refer to http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=sensor#sensor_imu
[Wrn] [ImuSensor.cc:91] Deprecation: IMU noise SDF value have changed. Please refer to http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=sensor#sensor_imu
[Wrn] [ImuSensor.cc:91] Deprecation: IMU noise SDF value have changed. Please refer to http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=sensor#sensor_imu
[Wrn] [ImuSensor.cc:91] Deprecation: IMU noise SDF value have changed. Please refer to http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=sensor#sensor_imu
[Wrn] [ImuSensor.cc:91] Deprecation: IMU noise SDF value have changed. Please refer to http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=sensor#sensor_imu
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:169] ServerFixture load in 1.1 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
[Err] [Visual.cc:2165] Unable to insert mesh[Cannot create GL vertex buffer]
world name: [default]
[Wrn] [HaptixControlPlugin.cc:152] no polhemus_source model detected using predefine location.
[Dbg] [HaptixControlPlugin.cc:159] Polhemus Source Pose [-0.5 0 1.3 3.14159 0 -1.57159]
libusb_open_device_with_vid_pid() failed
Failed to connect to Polhemus
[Wrn] [HaptixControlPlugin.cc:323] No usable polhemus setup detected.
Successfully connected to keyboard node
hxs_sim_info() Service call timed out.
/home/scpeters/ws/handsim/src/handsim/test/integration/sim_api.cc:167: Failure
Value of: hxOK
  Actual: 0
Expected: hxs_sim_info(&simInfo)
Which is: 1
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:118] ServerFixture::Unload
[  FAILED  ] SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo (2732 ms)
~~~

For the successful tests, I saw the `ServerFixture load` message after the `world name: [default]` message, but the failed tests had this message appearing first. That suggests an initialization problem. The `WorldPlugin`s and `ModelPlugin`s are not initialized until the first `World::Step`, so this PR takes a world step before calling `hxs_sim_info` to ensure that WorldPlugin's and ModelPlugin's have been loaded and makes the `SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo` test more reliable for me.
values.title: Improve SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo test reliability

~~~

For the successful tests, I saw the `ServerFixture load` message after the `world name: [default]` message, but the failed tests had this message appearing first. That suggests an initialization problem. The `WorldPlugin`s and `ModelPlugin`s are not initialized until the first `World::Step`, so this PR takes a world step before calling `hxs_sim_info` to ensure that WorldPlugin's and ModelPlugin's have been loaded and makes the `SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo` test more reliable for me.
summary.html:
While testing other pull requests, I saw some intermittent failures of the SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo test:

[ RUN      ] SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo
[Msg] Waiting for master.
[Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
[Msg] Publicized address: 172.23.2.90
[Wrn] [ImuSensor.cc:91] Deprecation: IMU noise SDF value have changed. Please refer to http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=sensor#sensor_imu
[Wrn] [ImuSensor.cc:91] Deprecation: IMU noise SDF value have changed. Please refer to http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=sensor#sensor_imu
[Wrn] [ImuSensor.cc:91] Deprecation: IMU noise SDF value have changed. Please refer to http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=sensor#sensor_imu
[Wrn] [ImuSensor.cc:91] Deprecation: IMU noise SDF value have changed. Please refer to http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=sensor#sensor_imu
[Wrn] [ImuSensor.cc:91] Deprecation: IMU noise SDF value have changed. Please refer to http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=sensor#sensor_imu
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:169] ServerFixture load in 1.1 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
[Err] [Visual.cc:2165] Unable to insert mesh[Cannot create GL vertex buffer]
world name: [default]
[Wrn] [HaptixControlPlugin.cc:152] no polhemus_source model detected using predefine location.
[Dbg] [HaptixControlPlugin.cc:159] Polhemus Source Pose [-0.5 0 1.3 3.14159 0 -1.57159]
libusb_open_device_with_vid_pid() failed
Failed to connect to Polhemus
[Wrn] [HaptixControlPlugin.cc:323] No usable polhemus setup detected.
Successfully connected to keyboard node
hxs_sim_info() Service call timed out.
/home/scpeters/ws/handsim/src/handsim/test/integration/sim_api.cc:167: Failure
Value of: hxOK
  Actual: 0
Expected: hxs_sim_info(&simInfo)
Which is: 1
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:118] ServerFixture::Unload
[  FAILED  ] SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo (2732 ms)

For the successful tests, I saw the ServerFixture load message after the world name: [default] message, but the failed tests had this message appearing first. That suggests an initialization problem. The WorldPlugins and ModelPlugins are not initialized until the first World::Step, so this PR takes a world step before calling hxs_sim_info to ensure that WorldPlugin's and ModelPlugin's have been loaded and makes the SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo test more reliable for me.

Also, changes a for loop to use the more concise c++11 syntax

values.description:
The log file was not created with the current code when calling `hxs_start_logging()`. This patch fixes the problem.

You can test it following the [HAPTIX logging tutorial](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-requests/280).
values.title: Fix HaptixStartLoggingCallback

summary.raw:
The log file was not created with the current code when calling `hxs_start_logging()`. This patch fixes the problem.

You can test it following the [HAPTIX logging tutorial](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-requests/280).
summary.html:
The log file was not created with the current code when calling hxs_start_logging(). This patch fixes the problem.

You can test it following the HAPTIX logging tutorial.
